discussion.content: Possible answers B and D. But D is the correct. B is parcially correct when use SRTM, but is incorrectc when propuse work with discrete task. D is correct because use a mthodology to verify, in that methodology you can work with SRTM.

B.

A security requirements traceability matrix (SRTM) is a grid that allows documentation and easy viewing of what is required for a system’s security. SRTMs are necessary in technical projects that call for security to be included.

B looks more accurate, no?
"SRTM is a matrix that makes it easy to identify the security requirements of a given system and the actual implementations or tests that can evaluate whether the requirement has been achieved."

questions.question_text:
A security engineer is working with a software development team. The engineer is tasked with ensuring all security requirements are adhered to by the developers.
Which of the following BEST describes the contents of the supporting document the engineer is creating?

choices.C: A set of formal methods that apply to one or more of the programing languages used on the development project.
choices.D: A methodology to verify each security control in each unit of developed code prior to committing the code.
choices.B: A series of discrete tasks that, when viewed in total, can be used to verify and document each individual constraint from the SRTM.
choices.A: A series of ad-hoc tests that each verify security control functionality of the entire system at once.

questions.question_text:
A security technician is incorporating the following requirements in an RFP for a new SIEM:
✑ New security notifications must be dynamically implemented by the SIEM engine
✑ The SIEM must be able to identify traffic baseline anomalies
✑ Anonymous attack data from all customers must augment attack detection and risk scoring
Based on the above requirements, which of the following should the SIEM support? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
Given answers make sense to me.
B. Machine learning
D. Big Data analytics

comments.content: "Anonymous attack data from all customers" - lots of customers, I think, is why Big Data Analytics is necessary.

choices.D: Configure and monitor devices with an MDM.
choices.A: Require frequent password changes and disable NFC.
choices.B: Enforce device encryption and activate MAM.

discussion.content: @TheSkyMan: The article says MAM does not support full device encryption but rather MDM. So the correct answer is D

comments.content:
The question specifies "Active full-device encryption." It seems that this cannot be done with MAM, you need MDM. 
https://www.infosys.com/mobility/white-papers/Documents/battle-MDM-MAM.pdf

D
Indeed, B contradicts itself. "Enforce encryption and activate MAM" -- how are you going to enforce encryption? With MDM. There's no other way. The answer has to be D.
Disagree that it is MAM (mobile application management) for reasons others have stated.

questions.question_text:
An organization enables BYOD but wants to allow users to access the corporate email, calendar, and contacts from their devices. The data associated with the user's accounts is sensitive, and therefore, the organization wants to comply with the following requirements:
✑ Active full-device encryption
✑ Enabled remote-device wipe
✑ Blocking unsigned applications
✑ Containerization of email, calendar, and contacts
Which of the following technical controls would BEST protect the data from attack or loss and meet the above requirements?

choices.A: Procure a password manager for the employees to use with the cloud applications.
choices.B: Create a VPN tunnel between the on-premises environment and the cloud providers.
choices.D: Implement an IdP that supports SAML and time-based, one-time passwords.
choices.C: Deploy applications internally and migrate away from SaaS applications.

discussion.content: The answer given is correct, D. IdP's are like Active Directory, and support SAML in order to pass authorization to service providers. IdP's also support OTPs and time based OTPs. The other answers don't seem to really address the question's mention of 2FA.

questions.question_text:
The Chief Information Officer (CIO) wants to increase security and accessibility among the organization's cloud SaaS applications. The applications are configured to use passwords, and two-factor authentication is not provided natively.
Which of the following would BEST address the CIO's concerns?

During a security assessment, activities were divided into two phases: internal and external exploitation. The security assessment team set a hard time limit on external activities before moving to a compromised box within the enterprise perimeter.
Which of the following methods is the assessment team most likely to employ NEXT?

discussion.content: ...so what phase are we at lol

comments.content:
Actually, C does not mention "social engineering" it mentions "social media." 
C. Exfiltrating network scans from the compromised box as a precursor to social media reconnaissance
Social media recon is not really social engineering. It is a form of Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) Gathering, or "passive reconnaissance." That is usually a first step in a pentest.

discussion.content: I feel from the key phrase compromised box that they're referencing pivoting from one machine to another. B & D both involve more external assessment things, and the question implies they're moving to exploit something internally, next, so that leaves A and C. I feel that C even mentioning social engineering should be the red flag against it as an answer. I'm fairly confident in A.

From the question: "... **before** moving to a compromised box within the enterprise perimeter." Then the question asks for the methods to be used "NEXT."
I am finding this to be a little confusing. Is the question asking what methods to use **before** getting on the compromised box and pivoting to the rest of the network?
Getting on the compromised box, and pivoting to the rest of the rest of the network would seem to make sense. The team has already penetrated the enterprise perimeter, and is on a compromised box. This means the team is well past the stages of social engineering and open-source intelligence gathering.

choices.A: Pivoting from the compromised, moving laterally through the enterprise, and trying to exfiltrate data and compromise devices.
choices.B: Conducting a social engineering attack attempt with the goal of accessing the compromised box physically.
choices.D: Open-source intelligence gathering to identify the network perimeter and scope to enable further system compromises.
choices.C: Exfiltrating network scans from the compromised box as a precursor to social media reconnaissance
